content:
Hello!
I want to use the SDL3 library I've been working on (https://github.com/ValorZard/lean-sdl3/) and integrate it with the larger Lean math/theorem proving stuff. An idea I wanted to explore was some sort of interactive theorem prover game.

Basically, what inspired me is the application StackRabbit (https://github.com/GregoryCannon/StackRabbit)

StackRabbit is an AI that plays the NES version of Tetris for you, and can calculate the most efficent path to get a a high score given a board. A similar application exists for chess (https://stockfishchess.org/)

I wonder if you could do something like this for lean. LIke, every step you take in the game, Lean generates a new path to the solution.

My feeling is that exploring proof space would be much harder than the space of possible actions in a board game and it might be much trickier if not impossible to get a reasonable heuristic about how "close" a goal is to being completed. Not only because at basically any goal you have the option to go to an unsolvable state using the wrong tactic.

Isn't this kind of what aesop does? Trying to generate a new path to the goal based on a few legal moves? and reap sounds like it would do the AI-version of this

I wonder if things are easier if you already have a working solution to start with and a partial proof which deviates from the sample solution.

At any rate, if you have some ideas which work reasonably well for simpler proofs, I always wanted to use something like that for an "auto-hint" at NNG, but I haven't spend much thought on it yet...
So I met someone at the Lean for PDEs event in UC Berkeley
And they showed me this game that kinda does what Iâ€™m talking about called Bombe
Basically your building mathematical proofs of minesweeper to get the game to automatically play it for you
And have to fill out more and more complex edgecases
It seems to use an embedded version of https://github.com/Z3Prover/z3
@Jon Eugster is this along the lines that you were thinking?

Thats a neat little game :)

think I slightly missunderstood your idea. I thought you wanted to proof some theorems say in algebra/analysis (where you know one sample solution) and have an AI which always tells you how to continue your proof taking the sample solution as inspiration.

I guess minesweeper is much simpler in that regard

in Bombe iirc the proving part is done completely automatically, you just have to state the theorems and it'll tell you if the theorem is true or if it's vacuously true or it will give you a counterexample
